Oreofe Olayemi's Terminal Basics Exercises

Part I

  1. mkdir first_folder
  2. cd first_folder
  3. touch person.txt
  4. mv person.txt another.txt
  5. cp another.txt copy.txt
  6. rm copy.txt
  7. cp -r first_folder second_folder
  8. rm -fr second_folder

Part II

  1. The command man brings out the manual for command on windows
  2. The -l flag lists all the files in a directory while the -a flag lists all the files in the directory including all hidden files.
  3. curl https://www.google.com > google.html
  4. less google.html . less
  5. less -p hplogo google.html
  6. You use left and right arrows to jump between words in terminals
  7. You use control + e to get to the end of a line in a terminal
  8. you use control + a to move cursor to the beginning in a terminal
  9. You press what you want to delete + delete key
  10. A terminal is an interface, an application that interacts with the computer while a shell is the program that processes commands and returns output
  11. An absolute path traces its path to the root. It shows the path to which directories and files are opened
  12. A relative path does not trace its path to the root. It jumps right into the file or directory.
  13. A flag gives additional commands to commands. Examples of 3 commands i have used are -r, -l-, -la
  14. The r and f flags when added to the rm command to become "rm rf" deletes an entire directory with the contents of the directory inclusive.
